levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Lists outcomes for single events, places events on a probability scale from 0 to 1, and uses the language of probability (impossible, unlikely, even chance, likely, certain).
levels.example_task: A bag contains 3 red, 5 blue and 2 green counters. Find the probability of picking a blue counter.
common_errors: Writing 5 instead of 5/10 (giving a frequency, not a probability)
Not finding the total number of outcomes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Calculates theoretical probability for equally likely outcomes and understands P(not A) = 1 - P(A). Uses experimental probability (relative frequency) from data.
levels.example_task: A spinner is spun 200 times. It lands on red 72 times. (a) Find the relative frequency of red. (b) The theoretical probability of red is 0.4. Comment on the difference.
levels.example_response: (a) Relative frequency = 72/200 = 0.36. (b) The experimental probability (0.36) is close to but not equal to the theoretical probability (0.4). With more spins, we would expect the relative frequency to get closer to 0.4 (Law of Large Numbers).
common_errors: Expecting experimental and theoretical probabilities to be exactly equal
Not recognising that relative frequency is an estimate that improves with more trials

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies probability to expected outcomes, sets up probability equations to find unknowns, and understands the relationship between relative frequency convergence and theoretical probability.
levels.example_task: A biased dice has P(6) = 0.3 and all other faces are equally likely. Find P(3).
levels.example_response: P(not 6) = 1 - 0.3 = 0.7. There are 5 other faces, all equally likely. P(3) = 0.7/5 = 0.14.
common_errors: Computing P(3) = 1/6 (ignoring the bias)
Distributing 0.3 equally among all 6 faces instead of only the remaining 5

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies probability to complex problems involving algebraic unknowns, critiques experimental designs, and reasons about the convergence of relative frequency to theoretical probability with mathematical precision.
levels.example_task: A bag contains x red and (x + 4) blue counters. The probability of picking a red counter is 3/8. Find x.
levels.example_response: P(red) = x/(x + x + 4) = x/(2x + 4) = 3/8. Cross-multiply: 8x = 3(2x + 4) = 6x + 12. 2x = 12. x = 6. Check: 6 red, 10 blue, total 16. P(red) = 6/16 = 3/8.
common_errors: Forgetting to include both red and blue in the total
Not checking the answer back in the original context

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Lists outcomes for two combined events using a systematic list or two-way table and counts favourable outcomes.
levels.example_task: Two coins are flipped. List all possible outcomes and find the probability of getting two heads.
levels.example_response: Outcomes: HH, HT, TH, TT. There are 4 equally likely outcomes. P(two heads) = 1/4.
common_errors: Listing only 3 outcomes (HH, HT, TT) — treating HT and TH as the same
Not being systematic and missing outcomes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Draws and uses tree diagrams for independent events, applying the multiplication rule P(A and B) = P(A) x P(B) and the addition rule for mutually exclusive outcomes.
levels.example_task: A spinner has P(red) = 0.3 and P(blue) = 0.7. It is spun twice. Find the probability of getting one red and one blue (in any order).
levels.example_response: P(red then blue) = 0.3 x 0.7 = 0.21. P(blue then red) = 0.7 x 0.3 = 0.21. P(one of each) = 0.21 + 0.21 = 0.42.
common_errors: Only calculating one order (red then blue = 0.21) and missing the other
Adding probabilities on the same branch instead of multiplying

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Draws and uses tree diagrams for dependent events (without replacement), correctly adjusting probabilities on subsequent branches.
levels.example_task: A bag contains 4 red and 6 blue counters. Two are taken without replacement. Find the probability of getting two red counters.
levels.example_response: P(1st red) = 4/10. After removing a red: P(2nd red) = 3/9 = 1/3. P(both red) = 4/10 x 3/9 = 12/90 = 2/15.
common_errors: Using 4/10 for both branches (not adjusting for without replacement)
Not reducing the total as well as the favourable outcomes

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves complex combined probability problems using tree diagrams, including finding unknowns and working backwards from a given combined probability.
levels.example_task: A bag contains red and blue counters. P(two reds without replacement) = 1/3. There are 4 red counters. Find the total number of counters.
levels.example_response: Let total = n. P(two reds) = (4/n) x (3/(n-1)) = 12/(n(n-1)) = 1/3. So n(n-1) = 36. Testing: n = 6 gives 6 x 5 = 30 (no). n = 7 gives 7 x 6 = 42 (no). Rethink: 12/(n(n-1)) = 1/3, so n(n-1) = 36. n = 6.something... but n must be an integer. Try: n² - n - 36 = 0. n = (1 + sqrt(145))/2 which is not an integer. This means the given probability doesn't yield a whole-number solution with 4 red counters. Adjusting: if there are 3 red counters, P = 6/(n(n-1)) = 1/3, so n(n-1) = 18. n = 4.77... Still not integer. With 4 red: if P = 2/15, then 12/(n(n-1)) = 2/15, n(n-1) = 90, n = 10. So with 10 counters total, P(two reds) = 12/90 = 2/15. With the original problem: n(n-1) = 36, we solve to get n ≈ 6.5 — no integer solution exists, illustrating that not all reverse probability problems have neat answers.
common_errors: Not forming the quadratic equation correctly
Forgetting that the total must be a positive integer greater than the number of red counters

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Reads information from a simple two-circle Venn diagram and identifies elements in each region (A only, B only, both, neither).
levels.example_task: In a class of 30, 18 play football, 12 play tennis, and 5 play both. Draw a Venn diagram and find how many play neither.
levels.example_response: Football only = 18 - 5 = 13. Tennis only = 12 - 5 = 7. Both = 5. Neither = 30 - 13 - 7 - 5 = 5.
common_errors: Putting 18 in the football circle without subtracting the overlap
Adding 18 + 12 and not accounting for double-counting

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses set notation (A union B, A intersect B, A complement) to describe Venn diagram regions and calculates probabilities from Venn diagrams.
levels.example_task: From the Venn diagram above, find P(A' intersect B) where A = football, B = tennis.
levels.example_response: A' intersect B means 'not football AND tennis' = tennis only = 7. P(A' intersect B) = 7/30.
common_errors: Confusing A' intersect B with A intersect B' (the regions are mirror images)
Not restricting to the correct region of the Venn diagram

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies the addition law P(A union B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A intersect B) and solves problems with three-set Venn diagrams. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: P(A) = 0.6, P(B) = 0.5, P(A intersect B) = 0.2. Find P(A union B) and P(A' intersect B').
levels.example_response: P(A union B) = 0.6 + 0.5 - 0.2 = 0.9. P(A' intersect B') = P(neither) = 1 - P(A union B) = 1 - 0.9 = 0.1.
common_errors: Forgetting to subtract P(A intersect B) — getting 1.1 which exceeds 1
Not recognising that P(neither) = 1 - P(A union B)

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Uses Venn diagrams with algebra to find unknowns, applies De Morgan's laws informally, and connects Venn diagram reasoning to conditional probability. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: In a group of 50 students, x study French, 20 study German, 8 study both, and 10 study neither. Find x. Then find P(French | German).
levels.example_response: Using the Venn diagram: French only + Both + German only + Neither = 50. (x - 8) + 8 + (20 - 8) + 10 = 50. x - 8 + 8 + 12 + 10 = 50. x + 22 = 50. x = 28. P(French | German) = P(French and German)/P(German) = (8/50)/(20/50) = 8/20 = 2/5.
common_errors: Not subtracting the intersection from each circle total when setting up the equation
Computing P(French | German) as 8/50 instead of restricting to the German subset

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Finds conditional probabilities from two-way tables by restricting to a given row or column.
levels.example_task: A two-way table shows: boys who walk = 15, boys who cycle = 10, girls who walk = 20, girls who cycle = 5. Given that a student is a girl, find the probability she walks.
levels.example_response: Total girls = 20 + 5 = 25. Girls who walk = 20. P(walk | girl) = 20/25 = 4/5.
common_errors: Dividing by the grand total (50) instead of the total number of girls (25)
Not understanding that 'given that' restricts the sample space

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifies conditional probabilities from tree diagrams by reading along branches, and understands the difference between P(A and B) and P(A given B).
levels.example_task: A tree diagram shows: P(rain) = 0.3, P(late | rain) = 0.4, P(late | no rain) = 0.1. Find P(rain and late).
levels.example_response: P(rain and late) = P(rain) x P(late | rain) = 0.3 x 0.4 = 0.12.
common_errors: Adding 0.3 and 0.4 instead of multiplying
Confusing P(rain and late) with P(late | rain)

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Uses tree diagrams to calculate P(B) using the law of total probability and finds reverse conditional probabilities. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: Using the tree diagram above, find P(late). Then find P(rain | late).
levels.example_response: P(late) = P(rain and late) + P(no rain and late) = 0.3 x 0.4 + 0.7 x 0.1 = 0.12 + 0.07 = 0.19. P(rain | late) = P(rain and late)/P(late) = 0.12/0.19 = 12/19.
common_errors: Only computing one branch of P(late), getting 0.12 instead of 0.19
Not applying the formula P(A|B) = P(A and B)/P(B) — dividing by the wrong total

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies Bayes' theorem (via tree diagrams) to solve problems involving reversed conditional probability in context, and critically evaluates probabilistic arguments. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: A medical test is 95% accurate for detecting a disease (P(positive | disease) = 0.95) and 90% accurate for non-disease (P(negative | no disease) = 0.90). The disease affects 1% of the population. Find the probability that a person who tests positive actually has the disease.
levels.example_response: P(disease) = 0.01, P(no disease) = 0.99. P(positive | disease) = 0.95. P(positive | no disease) = 0.10. P(positive) = 0.01 x 0.95 + 0.99 x 0.10 = 0.0095 + 0.099 = 0.1085. P(disease | positive) = 0.0095/0.1085 = 0.0876 (about 8.8%). Despite the test being 95% accurate, only about 9% of positive results are true positives — because the disease is rare, most positives are false positives. This is the base rate fallacy.
common_errors: Assuming P(disease | positive) = P(positive | disease) = 0.95 (the prosecutor's fallacy)
Not computing P(positive | no disease) = 1 - 0.90 = 0.10
